title: Furious gran makes huge 'all I want is a driveway' sign over parking space battle
text:

A pensioner fighting her local council over parking space has created a huge sign demanding a driveway.

Ann Sutton 72 wrote on a bedsheet "all I want is a driveway" and strung it up on her fence.

Her sign has been catching motorists' eyes in the village of Black Notley.

However the giant blue and green letter has so far failed to convince the council to give the widowed grandmother what she wants.

Braintree Council denied an application from Ann and her late husband for a driveway five years ag as the local Black Notley Parish Council said it would make the area look unattractive.

So the gran strung up a bedsheet in the driveway, reports Essex Live .

"People come up to me and say: 'That’s outside yours isn’t it Ann?' and I say, 'Yes that’s me.'

"Blow it, I’m leaving it up, let them moan."

She originally made the sign with paper letters, but they started falling off because of the rain.

"I went out and I took it down, and I went: 'No, I’m gonna paint it on and put it on my fence.'

"I’m going to leave it up so that it looks untidy if that’s what they're telling me I would do with a bit of tarmac.

The row has erupted because after Ann's husband passed away two years ago, she's now in danger of losing her disabled parking space on a street near her house.

If that happens, she'll be left with no nearby guaranteed parking space, something that may lead her having to park many roads away.

Ann and her late husband first applied for a driveway in 2014.

However Braintree Council denied their application after the local Black Notley Parish Council said the driveway would make the area look unattractive.

She now can't afford the money to apply again, in case they are denied once more.

Five years ago, Ann and her late husband, started looking into building a drive in front of their home.

At the time, they were having to park their car along a side road, which would often be too full to park down.

Her husband was granted a disabled space, which guaranteed the couple a nearby space to park in.

But after he died in 2017, the space is now not certain to stay available to Ann, leading to her reignited efforts for a driveway.

She got in touch again with the council, asking them to reconsider due to her new circumstances.

But the council refused unless she paid another fee to resubmit, which costs more than £200.

"I tried again, writing letters backwards and forwards," she said.

"They came back with: “Mrs Sutton can reapply but she won’t get it, and she can go to appeal.

"That I thought was really nasty, and got my back up a bit."

"If they said I would apply and get it I would gladly put in the plans that’s all I want to do," she added.

"Being a widow and pensioner, I cannot afford to lose money for them to dismiss it.

"They won’t come out to see me and I’ve asked twice for them to come out.

"I don’t want them to pay for it, I just want a yes, a guarantee that they’ll grant the plans if I put them in."

The council have also said that there wouldn't be enough room for a drive on the verge, despite cars frequently parking on the grass anyway

Frustrated by the council's response, Ann contacted Witham MP and Home Secretary Priti Patel, who, despite trying to get Ann a driveway, did not succeed.

It was at that point that Ann decided to take matters into her own hands and rolled out the bed sheet.

"Nobody would believe I would do it, but my grandson helped me and we did it, and I think everybody was shocked.

"I said: 'Well I wasn’t going back on my word.'"

"It’s been funny actually, when it first went up, people were slowing down to look.

"The dustcart came past and they’re pipping their hooters."

A Braintree District Council spokesperson, said: “This planning application was refused in 2014 because of the impact it would have on the character of the street and the lack of space within the site, compromising the safety of pedestrians and other drivers.

"The applicant did not appeal against the council’s decision.

"We have responded to correspondence explaining the reasons for refusal are still relevant and therefore would still be refused permission if she did reapply."
description: Ann Sutton just wants a driveway - but Black Notley Parish Council in Braintree says it would make the area look 'unattractive'
